column1: what are the 4 main classes of biomolecules
column2:
nucleic acids
proteins
carbohydrates
lipids

column1: what are some functions of nucleic acids
column2: information, catalysis

column1: what are some functions of proteins
column2: catalysis (enzymes), structure, signalling (eg spike protein on SARS-COV-2)

column1: what are some functions of carbohydrates
column2: energy, structure, signalling

column1: what are some functions of lipids?
column2: encapsulation (lipid layer/bilayer), signalling

column1: nucleic acids are made from
column2: nucleotides

column1: proteins are made from
column2: amino acids

column1: carbohydrates are made from
column2: monosaccharides

column1: DNA/RNA are polymers of
column2: nucleotides

column1: polypeptides are polymers of
column2: amino acids

column1: what is the difference between the sugars in DNA and RNA
column2: the sugar in DNA is missing a hydroxyl group at the 2' position (ie the sugar is 2'-deoxy-D-ribose)

column1: what is the difference between a nucleo<u>tide</u> and a nucleo<u>side</u>
column2: nucleotide contains phosphate, whereas nucleoside is just the base + sugar

column1: why are phosphate (phosphodiester) linkages strong and thus used in connecting nucleotides
column2: kinetically stable AND thermodynamically higher energy than its breakdown products

column1: how are VGICs named
describe the structure of Na and Ca VGICs
column2:
4 membered domain with each member consisting of 6 subunits (S1-S6). S1-S4 consist of the voltage-sensing region, whereas S5 and S6 and their pore loop are responsible for ion conduction and conmprise the gate and pore of the channel.
Na VGICs have an accessory β2/4 accessory subunit at the N terminus and a β1/3 accessory subunit at the C terminus
Ca VGICs have an accessory 𝛾 accessory subunit at the N terminus consisting of 4 subunits and an ⍺2∂ subunit at the C terminus

column1: what are TRP channels
column2:
TRP = transient receptor potential
often non-selective and can be activated by diff molecules

column1: describe the structure of TRP and K VGICs
column2: 4 membered domain w/ each member consisting of six subunits. However, different to Na and Ca channels, all four members are identical.

column1: what are some functions of β subunits of VGICs
column2:
- regulate expression levels, location & trafficking(where in membrane channel is expressed)
- alter voltage dependence of activation or inactivation
- can mind drugs that modulate function

column1: describe the structure of the pore and channel of VGICs
column2: 3Å wide "selectivity filter" lined w/ amino acid residues, determining what ion can/cannot pass through. then followed by a 10Å wide aqueous channel where the ion can pass through into the cell

column1: how do VGICs open
column2:
- open in response to change in membrane potential (change in concentration of ions on each side of membrane)
- VGICs contain a voltage sensor (S1-S4) which moves in response to change in membrane potential

column1: what is the difference between deactivation and inactivation of a VGIC
column2:
deactivation: when the membrane potential returns to its resting state and the channel may close

inactivation: the channel closes even when still depolarised. influx of +ve charge causes an intracellular domain to swing into open pore to block ion flow

column1: what are some examples of drugs that modulate Na<sub>v</sub> activity
column2:
tetrodotoxins
phenytoin and carbamazapine
local anesthetics

column1: how do tetrodotoxins modulate Na<sub>v</sub> activity
column2:
binds to the external surface of the ⍺ subunit of the channel in the S5-S6 loop region to block pore
used mainly as experimental tools to block Nav channels in vitro

column1: how do phenytoin and carbamazapine modulate Na<sub>v</sub> activity
column2:
slows recovery from inactived state (thus limits firing rate of neurons)
used in treatment of epilepsy

column1: how do local anesthetics modulate Na<sub>v</sub> activity
column2: binds to channel at sites exposed to lipid membrane, which blocks the channel

column1: what are some intracellular processes that entry of Ca<sup>2+</sup> causes
column2:
- muscle contraction
- neurotransmitter release
- activation of 2nd messenger systems (GPCRs?)
- alteration in gene expression
- apoptosis
- depolarization

column1: what is membrane depolarisation
column2:
a process that shifts the electrical charge distribution so that the cell is less negatively charged compared to the environment
ie intracellular is more +vely charged than extracellular

column1: how do gabapentin and pregabalin modulate Ca<sub>v</sub> channels
column2:
they bind to the ⍺2δ subunit to disrupt trafficking of the channel to the membrane
they're selective for Cav2.2 (N-type) channels that regulate neurotransmitter release in sensory neurones

column1: what are the two main TRP channels involved in pain perception
column2: TRPV1 and TRPA1

column1: what happens when TRPA1 and TRPV1 channels are activated
on which synaptic neuron(s) are GPCRs located?
column2: both pre and post synaptic

column1: describe the general structure of the membrane-bound portion of a GPCR (ie the part they all have in common)
column2:
7 transmembrane domain
each domain is an anti-clockwise ⍺ helix comprising of ~25-35 amino acids with a relatively high degree of hydrophobicity

column1: whatr type of extracellular domain do glutamate/class C GPCRs have and what does it do
column2: venus fly trap domain for binding ligand

column1: where is the binding pocket within rhodopsin/class A GPCRs
column2: deep within extracellular mouth

column1: how does a GPCR move from its inactive to active state?
column2: conformational switch of 7TM domain (ie ⍺ helices move), mainly TM6 which moves

column1: what effect does activation of a GPCR have on the g-protein
column2: movement of TM6 slightly dislodges ⍺ subunit of g-protein, which triggers conversion GDP (inactive) --> GTP (active), which is then released from ⍺ subunit

column1: what are the 3 subtypes of the ⍺ subunit and what does their subscript mean?
column2:
Gs = stimulatory
Gi/o = inhibitory
Gq = quirky

column1: what happens when a GPCR becomes activated that has a G<sub>s</sub> subtype G-protein
column2:
GDP --> GTP
GTP then binds to adenylyl cyclase which makes ATP --> cAMP
cAMP then binds to protein kinase A which then performs many functions

column1: what happens when a GPCR becomes activated that has a Gi subtype G-protein
column2: Gi subunit also on adenylyl cyclase (AC), so GTP from Gi protein of GPCR unable to bind to AC and make ATP --> cAMP thus leaving protein kinase A inactivated

column1: what does protein kinase A (PKA) do/do to neuronal activity?
column2:
can phosphorylate and alter activity of signalling proteins
can enter nucleus and alter transcruption of important synaptic proteins
presynaptically: ⇑ neurotransmitter release thru action on vesicle release machine
postsynaptically: can phosphorylate transcription factors & upregulate transcription of important synaptic proteins

column1: how is the Gq subunit different to Gs and Gi
column2: Gq has no effect on AC (ie does not produce any cAMP). through a series of rxns its activation releases Ca2+ from intracellular stores

column1: what are some types of Gs, Gi, and Gq subunits
column2:
Gs: D1R, β1R
Gi: D2R, ⍺2AR
Gq: M1R, ⍺1AR

column1: what happens when a GPCR with Gq subtype G protein is stimulated
column2: GTP released by Gq stimulates phospholipase-C then protein kinase-C and mobilises calcium

column1: how does nature add a new nucleotide to a growing chain
what is a phosphoramidite and why is it used for synthetic DNA synthesis
column2:
phosphoramidite = P bonded to two O and one N
P centre is in lower oxidation state and there is less -vely charged oxygens (like in phosphate) thus is is a better nucleophile

column1: what is chemoselectivity
column2: controlling which functional group will react when there is >1 that can

column1: what are protecting groups and why are they important
column2:
protecting groups are often bulky substituents that can 'hide' or 'protect' functional groups from reacting
important for controlling chemoselectivity
e.g. DMT which is always attached to 5' oxygen

column1: the amine of a phosphoramidite is not a good leaving group. how is this barrier overcome?
column2:
use of a catalyst tetrazole

nitrogen within tetrazole then attacks H of 5' hydroxyl of next nucleoside. deprotonated 5' oxygen then attacks P and protonated tetrazole leaves.

column1: how is the phosphite P<sup>III</sup> turned into phosphate P<sup>V</sup> after tetrazole leaves during syntyhetic DNA synthesis
column2: oxidation by a base (2,6-lutidine) in the presence of aqueous iodine I<sub>2 </sub>

column1: how are the remaining protecting groups cleavedin synthetic DNA synthesis and when is this step performed
column2:
cleaved with ammonia (expcept for DMT which is cleaved with trichloroacetic acid)
happens after all nucleosides have been connected as it also cleaves the oligo from the glass bead at the last 3' oxygen

column1: what is the driving force in helix formation
column2: hydrophobic effect - nucleobases are mostly hydrophobic so it is more entropically favourable to bury them inside together and have the hydrophilic phosphate facing outwards

column1: what are intercalators
column2:
molecules which are able to insert themselves into a DNA strand and stack between base pairs (π-π sracki
normally polycyclic, lots of aromaticity, have  4º amine to interact w phosphate
eg

column1: what are DNA alkylators/crosslinkers
column2: good electrophiles which can interact w DNA

column1: what is the isoelectric point (pI) of an amino acid & how is it calculated
column2:
the pH at which an amino acid is in all its zwitterionic form (ie overall net neutral charge)
the average of two pKa values

column1: why are amide bonds the bond used in peptides?
column2:
amides are v stable to hydrolysis
overlap between N lone pair and C=O π* orbital makes carbonyl group less reactive

column1: under which conditions is Fmoc removed?
column2:
basic conditions 
ie it is 'base-labile'

column1: under which conditions is Boc removed?
column2:
acidic conditions
ie it is 'acid-labile'

column1: draw the mechanism for how Fmoc is added to a peptide vis Fmoc-Cl mechanism
draw the mechanism for how Boc is added to a peptide (via Boc anhydride)
column2: CO2 bubbles off

column1: draw the mechanism for Fmoc deprotection in basic conditions (base is piperidine)
draw the mechanism for how Boc is removed w acid
side chains are procted with ____-labile groups
column2: acid

column1: what type of protecting group is used on the COO- of a peptide and why are they used?
column2:
DCC/HOtBt
used because they activate the carbonyl to make it more reactive as an electrophile. DCC contains a carbodiimide
x

column1: draw the mechanism for addition and removal of DCC to an amino acid (use glycine being added to lysine)
why is HOBt a better activating group than DCC?
column2: less prone to epimerisation (intramolecular scrambling at stereocentre)

column1: how does nature couple amino acids?
column2: all occurs at ribosome

column1: why are amide bonds used in nature/so strong?
column2:
resistant to hydrolysis
C-N has partial double bond character due to resonance

column1: what makes an amino acid have the 'L' con figuration
column2: H2N is on the left hand side in a fischer projection

column1: what is the hydrophobic effect and why does it occur
column2: non-polar/aliphatic/hydrophobic residues bury themselves within the protein so they do not come in contact w/ water. this is entropically favourable as it frees water molcules instead of water having to orient itself around these residues.

column1: what are disulfide bonds
column2:
covalent bonds that form between two thiol residues (cysteine or methionine)
can be intra or inter chain linkages

column1: what are six general classes of enzymes and what do they do?
column2:
1. oxidoreductases (redox rxns)
2. transferases (transfer of molecules)
3. hydrolyases (hydrolysis)
4. lysases (other cleavage rxns)
5. isomerases (isomerisation of chiral centres)
6. ligases (addition of a group)

column1: what are proteases
column2: enzymes that hydrolyse peptide bonds

column1: what is the difference between a serine protease and cysteine protease
column2:
a serine protease has a serine residue in its catalytic active site
a cysteine protease has a cysteine residue in its catalytic active site

column1: what is the difference between an endo- and exo-protease
column2:
exo-proteases cleaves peptide bonds from the end of a polypeptide chain
endo-proteases cleave peptide bonds in a specific place in the middle of a chain

column1: draw the mechanism of peptide cleavage by a serine protease
what are some techniques used in determining the tertiary sturcture of a protein
column2:
NMR spectroscopy
X-ray crystallography
Cryo-electron microscopy

column1: what are cofactors
column2: biological reagents involved in enzyme catalysis

column1: what is NADH/NAD+/NADPH, what does it do and which part of the molecule reacts?
column2:
nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
source of hydride H- (reduces carbonyl groups in vivo)

column1: what is FAD, what function does it serve, and which part of the molecule reacts?
column2:
Flavin adenine dinucleotide
Redox coupling (FAD = H- acceptor, FADH2 = H- donator)
opposite nitrogens react

column1: what is SAM, what function does it serve, and which part of the molecule reacts?
column2:
S-adenosyl methionine
Methylating agent
methyl substituent on sulfonium linkage gets removed by a nucleophile

column1: what function does pyridoxal phosphate serve and which part of the molecule reacts?
column2:
Activates amino acids
N of amino acid will attack aldehyde to form an imine which can then act as a nucleophile

column1: what is CoA/AcCoA, what function does it serve and which part of the molecule reacts?
column2:
Acetyl Coenzyme A transfers acetyl groups and so on (eg can also transfer malonyl groups and so on...)
Large molecular crane with terminal thiol --> thiol is the real workhorse of the molecule

column1: why and thus how do thioesters react differently to esters?
column2:
orbital overlap in a thioester is poor, 3p of S and 2p of carbon do not overlap well
THUS - hydrolysis and enolisation of thioesters is much easier

column1: what is one major function of acetyl CoA?
column2: build up fatty acids

column1: how are L/D configuartions assigned?
column2:
in a fischer projection...
- focus on penultimate carbon (ie last stereogenic centre)
- if high priority group if RHS, then it is D
- if high priority group is LHS, then it is L

column1: where are the aldehyde/ketone and -CH2OH positioned in a fischer projection?
column2:
aldehyde/ketone on top
CH2OH on bottom

column1: L and D glucose are _____ of one another
column2: enantiomers

column1: what are epimers?
column2:
changing the configuration at just one of the stereogenic carbons in a sugar
e.g. Mannose is the C2 epimer of glucose

column1: draw the general mechanism for the acid catalysed cyclisation of glucose
what is the difference between β-glucose and ⍺-glucose
column2:
β-glucose has -OH of hemi-acetal pointing up (above ring, adjacent w 1º alcohol)
⍺-glucose has -OH of hemi-acetal pointing down (below ring)

column1: β-glucose and ⍺-glucose are known as _____
column2:
anomers
and the hemiacetal centre is the anomeric centre

column1: what is the conversion between two anomers known as?
column2: mutarotation

column1: what is the anomeric effects?
column2:
tetrahydropyran = 6 membered ring w/ an oxygen
axial = pointing down. opposite is equitorial, which are facing out of ring (on same plane as ring)
this means that the ⍺ anomer of glucose is favoured

column1: why is ⍺-glucose more present in solution than β-glucose
column2: the axial conformation allows a favourable orbital interaction

column1: what are the general names for a 5 and 6 membered ring form of a sugar?
column2:
6 = pyranose
5 = furanose
name comes from:

column1: if you reduce the C1 carbon of glucose, what product do you attain? draw and name the product
column2: product is an alditol.

column1: what happens if you oxidise the C1 carbon of glucose? draw and name the product
column2: product is gluconic aicd (general name is aldonic acid)

column1: what happens if you oxidise the C6 of glucose? name and draw the product and identify the enzyme that catalyses this reaction
column2:
product is glucuronic acid (general name is uronic acid)

enzyme = glucose oxidase

column1: what happens when the hemiacetal of glucose reacts with alcohol? draw the mechanism and name the product
column2:
product is an glycoside (an acetal). H+ catalysed

new bond is called a GLYCOSIDIC BOND

column1: how are linkages between two sugars named?
column2:
start w/ LHS sugar, is it ⍺ or β? 
linkage always starts from C1 on LHS sugar.
which carbon is the oxygen making a bond on the RHS sugar? 
e.g. if C4 and the LHS carbon is β, the linkage is β(1-->4)
e.g. lactose

column1: what are amino sugars?
column2: sugars in which one -OH is replaced by an amine

column1: what are the 5 monoamine neurotransmitters and what are the two classes?
column2:
catacholamines:
- dopamine
- norepinephrine
-epinephrine
indoleamines:
- serotonin (5-HT)
- melatonin

column1: describe the synthesis of the catecholamine neurotransmitters
column2:
1. Tyrosine hydroxylase adds -OH substituent to L-tyrosine to form L-DOPA
2. L-aromatic acid decarboxylase removes -COOH of L-DOPA to form dopamine (dopaminergic neurons stop synthesising here)
3. Dopamine β hydroxylase adds -OH to β carbon from NH2 to form norepinephrine (noradrenergic neurons stop synthesising here)
4. PNMT adds methyl substituent to NH2 of NE to form epinephrine

column1: describe 5-HT synthesis
column2:
1. Tryptophan hydroxylase adds -OH substituent to indole ring (C opposite that C in benzene ring bonded to N is, '5' position?)
2. L-aromatic acid decarboxylase removes -COOH to form 5-HT

column1: describe "traditional" synaptic release
column2:
1. terminal depolarisation
2. Ca2+ channel opens and Ca2+ influxes
3. Ca2+ entry promotes fusion of vesicles to the membrane
4. exocytosis of monoamine NT into synapse

column1: where are 5-HT and NA also released from?
column2: also released from varicosities ("buds" that come off axons)

column1: what are some drugs that target monoamine synthesis?
column2:
-L-DOPA (can be given as a drug, ⇑DA)
- dietary tryptophan (⇑ 5-HT)
- MDMA (inhibits tryptophan hydroxylase, ⇓ 5-HT)

column1: what are some drugs that target storage and release of monoamines?
column2:
- amphetamines (disrupt storage, ⇑ DA)
- Resperine (disrupts stoage of NA in vesicular transporter storage)

column1: where is NA synthesised?
column2: locus coeruleus

column1: where is 5-HT synthesised
column2: raphe nuclei

column1: where is dopamine synthesised?
column2:
ventral tegmental area
substantia nigra

column1: how are monoamines reuptaked from the synapse?
column2:
active transport via high affinity Na+ dependent membrane transport protein
DAT, NAT, SERT

column1: what are some drugs that target monoamine transport
column2:
- cocaine (block DAT, ⇑DA)
- amitriptyline (block NAT and SERT)

column1: how are monoamines degraded?
column2:
in neurons by oxidative deamination by monoamine oxidase (MAO)
MAO isoforms:
- MAO-A (degrades 5-HT, NA, Adr, DA)
- MAO-D (degrades DA)
catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) also involved, usually on extraneuronal locations

column1: describe how DA is degraded
column2:
2 pathways:
1) COMT degrades DA to 3-MT, then MAO converts 3-MT to homovanillic acid (HVA)
2) MAO converts DA to DOPAC, then COMT coverts DOPAC to HVA

column1: describe NA degradation
column2:
2 pathways:
1) COMT coverts to normatadrenaline, then MAO-A converts to MOPGAL, then Aldehyde dehydrogenase forms vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)
2) MAO-A converts to DOPGAL, then Aldehyde dehydrogenase converts DOPGAL to DOMA, then COMT converts DOMA to VMA

column1: describe 5-HT degradation
column2:
1. MAO converts to 5-hydroxyindole acetalaldehyde
2. Aldehyde dehydrogenase then converts into 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA)

column1: what are some drugs that target monoamine degradation
column2: - moclobemide (inhibits MAO-A, ⇑[monoamine])

column1: identify drug targets within the monoamine system
column2:
- synthesis
- storage & release
- receptors
- uptake
- degradation

column1: what is the main difference between small molecule NTs and neuropeptides?
column2:
amino acid NTs --> mainly fast receptors (excitation)
monoamine NTs --> mainly slow receptors (modulatory)
neuropeptides --> mainly slow receptors (modulatory), most are only active locally

column1: what is a neuropeptide? & what are some examples
column2:
"a small protein or polypeptide which acts as a neurotransmitter in the nervous system"
some neuropeptides also act as hormones (eg oxytocin)

column1: describe the synthesis of neuropeptides
column2:
neuropeptide synthesis:
- requires transcription and translation
- cleavage of N terminus creates propeptide (like a prodrug - can become something useful)
- propeptide packed into dense vesicles and undergoes post-translational modifications to become neuropeptide

column1: what are the key differences between small molecule NT and neuropeptide synthesis?
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the storage and release of neuropeptides
column2:
- ~10,000 neuropeptides packed into dense core vesicles (NOT refilled locally)
- released from many sites on neuron, have many different release proteins and Ca2+ sensitivity

column1: what are the key differences between the storage and release of small molecule NTs and neuropeptides?
column2: #NAME?

column1: what are the key difference between the termination of action of small molecule NTs and neuropeptides?
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the action of neuropeptides
column2:
- mostly act on GPCRs
- very high affinity for their receptor (in nM range)
- act at auto, post or extra-synaptic receptors
- some peptides act at multiple receptors, some receptors have multiple peptide agonists

column1: what are the key differences between the action of small molecule NTs and neuropeptides?
column2: #NAME?

column1: what are the two major classes of pain relieving drugs?
column2:
1. opioids (morphine, codeine, oxycodone)
2. opioid-sparing drugs --> to be used in combination w/ opioids (NSAIDs etc)

column1: describe the three subtypes of opioid receptors and some of their functions
column2:
1. µ - strong analgesia, constipation, nausea, respiratory depression, tolerance & dependence (nearly all clinical opioids target µOR)
2. δ - spinal analgesia, convulsions?, cardiac complications
3. κ - moderate analgesia, hallucinations, diuersis

column1: describe opioid action at the spinal cord
column2:
nociceptors on primary afferent neurons fire after noxious stimuli and synapse in the dorsal horn of spinal cord.
two types of sensory fibres/primary afferent neurons --> C fibres and Aδ fibres
C fibres are non-myelinated and do slow, throbbing pain. Most opioids act on C fibres]
Aδ fibres are lightly-myelinated and do immediate pain.

column1: describe the physiological consequence of opioid agonism on µORs. refer to receptor location and structure.
column2:
µORs are located pre and post synapse.
pre synapse --> µORs inhibit Cavs (β𝛾) and adenylyl cyclase (⍺). inhibition of N-type Cavs inhibits NT release and reduces synaptic potentials
post synapse --> µORs open GIRK (K+) channels (β𝛾). opening GIRK blocks action potential and hyperpolarises cell membrane
Cav inhibition and GIRK opening β𝛾 subunit is main MOA for analgesia

column1: describe different endogenous opioids and in which cells they act
column2:
1. proenkephalin (nerve cells, adrenal). act on µ
2. prodynorphin (nerve cells). act on κ
3. ⍺-neoendorphin. activate µ
4. pro-opiomelanocortin (pituitary, brain-restricted)
A lot of these endogenous opioids/hormones are polypeptides

column1: describe morphine related opioids and metabolites
column2:
- heroin & codeine are prodrugs. they turn into morphine once in body.
- morphine has a hydroxyl substituent on phenyl ring (one not closest to nitrogen)
- heroin has an acetyl group instead of H (ie its an ester in that position). heroin is turned into active metabolite by an esterase.
- codeine has a methyl group instead of H (ie its a methyl ester in that position). codeine is turned into its active metabolite by CYP2D6.

column1: what does the strength of a G protein signalling depend on?
column2:
1. intrinsic efficacy of agonist (not same as potency)
2. capacity of receptors to signal
3. capacity of cell to translate signal
4. tolerance modifies capacity of receptor and cell to signal

column1: how does buprenorphine act on µORs
column2: buprenorphine is a partial agonist. it binds very tightly to µOR (so other agonists and antagonists cant bind) and produces a weak G protein signal. weaker signal = lessened response (incl no high or respiatory depression), so is used for ppl who have opioid dependence (sorta like methadone)

column1: how/why are 5-HT and NA transporter inhibitors work for analgesia?
column2:
- 5-HT2,3 'excites' inhibitory neurons synapsing onto ascending projection neurons & reduces ascending pain transmission
- NA acts on ⍺2 (Gi/o) on projection neurons and reduces their excitability

column1: what is the role of prostaglandins (PGE2) in nociception? and what is the MOA of NSAIDs and give some examples
column2: #REF!

column1: what is the difference between pain and nociception
column2:
nociception = activation of nociceptors 
pain = entire physical and psychological experience

column1: what is inflammatory pain?
column2:
tissue injury and inflammation processes
often ongoing after nociceptor activity --> maintains the pain

column1: what is neuropathic pain?
column2:
lesion or disease affecting the somatosensory system
causes:
1. trauma to peripheral nerves
2. central injury
3. disease
4. chemotherapy

column1: what are the symptoms of chronic pain?
column2:
1. spontaneous pain
2. allodynia (normally innocuous stimuli interpreted as painful)
3. hyperalgesia (painful stimuli more painful)

column1: what are the current pharmacotherapies available for chronic pain?
column2:
- anticonvulsants: Gabapentin (blocks Cav)
- Cav channel blocker
- antidepressants: TCAs, SNRIs
- opioids
- Tramadol (partial opioid agonist + SNRI)
- topical drugs (capsaicin, anesthetics e.g. lignocaine)

column1: what are some methods used to test chronic pain in animals?
column2:
- induce neuropathic pain in animal e.g. sciatic nerve partial damage
- measure mechanical allodynia: pressure test on paw. measure # of pain responses
- measure cold allodynia: acetone drop on paw. measure # of pain responses
- measure mechanical or thermal hyperalgesia: heat or pressure test on paw. measure # of pain responses

column1: how do drugs produce analgesia through targeting the pain pathways?
column2:
- decrease ascending transmission (inhibit ascending pathway)
- activate descending pathway which then release NTs in spinal cord to stop ascending pathway

column1: how is the physiology of the CNS different in those w/ neuropathic pain?
column2:
injury of peripheral afferents causes:
- hypotrophism (less nerve & brain derived growth factors which support nerves)
- inflammatory immune response
- increased expression of diff VGCs such as Nav1.7, Cav, TRPV1
all this reduces the activation threshold and causes spontaneous pain

allodynia is caused by nerve sprouting & non-noxious afferents activate pain ciruits

column1: why do opioids not work well in neuropathic pain?
column2:
- reduction in µORs 
- µORs not expressed on non-noxious afferents
- still some reduction in activation of ascending pain pathway but not as effective as acute --> also can't use opioids chronically for chronic pain

column1: how do Cav blockers, such as ziconotide, treat chronic pain?
column2:
- ziconotide targets N-type Cav2.2 which are expressed on all afferents in CNS and PNS so needs to be administered intrathecally
- greater expression of Cav on afferents in chronic pain so better for targeting allodynia
- Ca causes NT release so blocking this decreases NT release

column1: how do Gabapentin and Pregablin treat chronic pain?
column2:
1. bind to ⍺2δ subunit of Cav2.2 and Cav2.1
2. decrease Cav expression in central terminal of afferents
3. less NT release and less excitation
4. reduces pain transmission

dosage is hard bc you're trafficking Cav not blocking. not effective for all chronic pain patients. abuse potential

column1: how are TCAs and SNRIs used to treat chronic pain?
column2:
- both drug classes block NA and 5HT transporters
- 5HT activates central descending systems and mood modulation of pain systems
- NA released from descending pathway to inhibit ascending pathway. NA acts on ⍺2 (Gi/o) on primary afferent terminals to reduce glutamate release and dorsal horn neurons to directly inhibit ascending pain pathway

column1: how is capsaicin used to treat chronic pain?
column2:
- agonises TRPV1 LGICs predominantly expressed on C fibres and sense painful heat (above 40ºC)
- anti-nociceptive effect attributed to "defunctionalisation" of nociceptive fibres

column1: what is the pathogenesis of headaches/migraines?
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the neurogenic inflammation theory of migraine
column2:
1. intracranial blood vessel constricts
2. trigeminal ganglion releases CGRP 
3. TGN projects to trigeminal nucleus caudalis (brainstem)
4. TNC projects to ventroposterior medial thalamus 
5. VMT projects to somatosensory and causes pain

severity of migraine is proportional to amount of CGRP released. CGRP release triggers CGRP synthesis

column1: what happens in the serotonin system during a migraine
column2: - increase in 5HIAA (primary metbolite) during attack and decrease of 5HT

column1: what are the different types of 5HT receptors?
column2:
- 5-HT1A/B/D/E/F Gi/o coupled
- 5-HT2A/B/B Gs coupled

column1: describe 5-HT receptor expression in the trigeminovascular pathway
column2:
- trigeminal ganglion: 5-HT1B/1D
- trigeminal nucleus caudalis (brainstem): 5-HT1B/1D/1F
targeting these receptors reduces noxious signalling

column1: what are some drugs used to treat migraines in an acute manner (ie during an attack) and describe their MOA
column2:
- NSAIDs --> inhibit COX1/2 to decrease prostaglandin synthesis
- ergotamines --> 5-HT1D partial agonist, blocks trigeminal nerve transmission
- triptans --> 5-HT1B/1D/1F agonists, inhibit trigeminal nerve transmission centrally and peripherally and inhibits release of vasoactive peptides from trigeminal ganglia

column1: what drugs are used to treat migrane prophylactically (ie preventative)?
column2:
- β-adrenoreceptor agonists
- antidepressants (TCAs)
- 5-HT2 antagonists
- anticonvulsants
- Cav blocker
- CGRP receptor monoclonal antibodies

column1: how do 5-HT<sub>2</sub> antagonists treat migraine prophylactically?
column2:
e.g. pizotifen
- prevents 5-HT2 mediated vasodilation (2º to NO) and consequent inflammation
- side effects: weight gain, antimuscarinic

column1: how do anticonvulsants treat migraine prophylactically?
column2:
e.g. sodium valproate, gabapentin
- reduce cortical excitability by altering Cav activity
- decreases trigeminal neurotransmission
- teratogenic

column1: what is epilepsy & what is the cause?
column2: #NAME?

column1: what are the two main types of seizures. what are the specific types of seizures?
column2:
two main:
1. focal seizures --> begin in one area of brain
2. generalised seizures --> occurs w/ all areas of brain being hyper excitable
specific types:
- tonic-clonic --> stiff, jerking
- absence  --> blanking out
- myoclonic --> jerking/twitching of muscles
- infantile --> stiff & movement of head & limbs back and forth

column1: describe the symptoms and pathogenesis of Dravet syndrome
column2:
- severe encephalopathy w high seizure burden
- 80% of cases due to loss of function mutation in SCN1A gene (codes for ⍺ subunit of Nav1.1)

column1: describe the symptoms and pathogenesis of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
column2:
- severe encephalopathy w high seizure burden (infantile, tonic, absence)
- causes: structural, genetic (D120N mutation --> GABAA β3 subunit)

column1: describe the MOA of different antiseizure drugs
column2:
1. modulating VGICs (inhibition & enhancement of inactivation) e.g. lamotrigine
2. enhancing GABA-mediated inhibition e.g. benzodiazepines (diazepam PAM of GABAA)
3. interacing w/ synaptic release machinery e.g. levetiracetam binds synaptic vesicle glycoprotein
4. block ionotropic glutamate receptors e.g. perampanel blocks AMPA
5. combination of mechanisms e.g. cannabidiol, valproate

column1: describe preclinical models of epilepsy
column2:
- screening against conventional epilepsy drug targets (5HT, GABAA)
- diff models used for screening: zebrafish & rodents --> good phenotypic relevance but very low human/patient relevance
- KO or KI of SCN1A to test Dravet

column1: describe the neural circuitry that regulates mood
column2:
1. frontal cortex (FC) and hippocampus (HC) involved in cognition
2. nucleus accumbens (NAc) and amygdala (Amy) involved in emotion (NAc --> rewarding, Amy --> aversive)
3. hypothalamus (Hyp) anc monoamine brainstem nuclei (DR, LC) involved in vegetative symptoms e.g. appetite, energy

column1: describe the monoamine hypothesis of depression
column2:
- hypoNA/hypo5-HT state leads to receptor hyperresponsiveness
- SO antidepressants lead to ⇑ NA and ⇑ 5-HT
- AND down-regulating receptors to normal levels accounts for slow action of drugs

column1: describe the neuroendocrine hypothesis of depression
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the neurotrophic/neuroplasticity hypothesis of depression
column2:
stress & depression associated w:
- neuronal loss in pFC and Hyp (has been seen on imaging)
- ⇓ BDNF & TrKB receptors
- ⇓ neurogenesis
- maybe a genetic polymorphism in BDNF which predicts chronicity

column1: describe the current drug classes used to treat depression and give an example
column2:
- TCAs e.g. amitryptaline
- SSRIs e.g. fluoxetine
- SNRIs e.g. venlafaxine
- MAOA and MOAB inhibitors e.g. phenelzine
also tetracyclics and NRIs

column1: describe the MOA of SSRIs/SNRIs
column2:
- block presynaptic 5-HT and NA transporters
- causes ⇑ [5-HT, NA]

column1: describe the MOA of TCAs w reference to a hypothesis of depression
column2:
- block presynaptic 5-HT and NA transporters
- causes ⇑ [5-HT, NA]
- monoamine hypothesis states brain is in hypo5HT/hypoNA state, so increasing 5HT and NA rectifies this
- TCAs also block mAChR, 5HTR, ⍺-adrenoreceptors ∴⇑ side effects

column1: describe the MOA of MAO inhibitors
column2:
- inhibit breakdown of 5HT and NA
- increases cytoplasmic conc of monoamines
- increases leakage of monoamines into synapse

column1: describe the MOA of tetracyclic antidepressants
column2:
- block ⍺2 adrenoceptors
- causes increase 5HT and NA release

column1: describe the MOA of St John's Wart
column2: - block 5HT, NA, DA, GABA and glutamate reuptake by reducing Na<sup>+</sup> gradient

column1: compare the different side effects of different drug classes used to treat depression
column2:
- TCAs have the most antimuscarinic effects (eg blurred vision, dry mouth) and cardiovascular (eg arrythmias)
- SSRIs have most gastrointestinal side effects (eg nausea) and CNS (eg dizziness)
- MAO-I's have cheese reaction (if you eat food w tryamine eg cheese it can be fatal)

column1: describe how antidepressants treat depression w reference to the monoamine hypothesis
column2:
- down-regulate postsynaptic NA (β-adrenoceptors) and/or 5-HT2 recpetors (Gs)
- increase activity/sensitivity of postsynaptic 5-HT1 (Gi/o) receptors in hippocampus
- desensitisation of presynaptic ⍺2 adrenoceptors (Gi/o) and 5-HT1 receptors which control 5HT and NA release --> facilitates monoamine release
Net effect of chronic treatment is an enhancement of monoaminergic function

column1: describe how antidepressants treat depression w reference to the neurotrophic/neuroplasticity hypothesis
column2:
- antidepressants enhance BDNF signalling, TrKB receptors and neurogenesis
--> BDNF stimulates SERT transcription in raphe nuclei, 5HT receptor activation stimulates BDNF expression, thus ⇑ 5HT synthesis, release and cell function this may work to restore network function and in turn mood
- 5HT and NA promote neurogenesis by 5-HT1A, 5-HT2B and β-adrenoceptor stimulation and ⍺2-adrenoceptor blockade

column1: describe how antidepressants treat depression w reference to the neuroendocrine hypothesis
column2:
- antidepressants are associated w glucocorticoid receptor (GR) phosphorylation via PKA, which ⇑ inhibition of GR to promote neurogenesis in Hipp
- hippocampal neurogenesis is necessary for restoration of HPA axis (ie to inhibit stress response)

column1: what is drug addiction?
column2:
"a state where drug use continues in spite of serious potential or actual harm to the user or others"
"addiction is a brain disorder that results from a mix of genetic, neural, environmental and social causes"

column1: describe the role of genetics in addiction w reference to impulsivity
column2:
- alcoholism is strongest in terms of genetics
- highly impulsive (HI) humans have a high risk of drug abuse 
- HI humans have different cortical structures and dopamine receptor expression

column1: describe how chronic drug uses effects neuroplasticity with reference to chronic opioid use
column2:
neuroplasticity effected by:
1. tolerance --> ⇓ response to same dose, can be due to changed receptor response
2. counter-adaptations --> attempts to compensate for ongoing drug effects on cells, causes withdrawal and craving

with chronic opioid use, AC signalling becomes hypertrophied (up-regulated) which causes ⇑ cAMP and ⇑ excitation

column1: describe the important sites of opioid action in the brain
column2:
- VTA --> NAc is the reward pathway. opioids stimulate µORs on dopamine neurons in this pathway to cause euphoria
- medulla --> respiratory depression, depression, blood pressure, arousal, nausea

column1: describe how µOR antagonists are used to treat opioid addiction, describe the clinical effects and give an example
column2:
naltrexone
- occupies receptor and prevents binding 
- need to detox before use
- poor compliance
- high relapse rate

column1: describe how µOR agonists are used to treat opioid addiction, describe the clinical effects and give an example
column2:
methadone
- agonist w/ long half life ~22h --> good for dosing
- stops withdrawal and craving w/o intoxication at correct dose
- overdose possible

column1: describe how µOR partial agonists are used to treat opioid addiction, describe the clinical effects and give an example
column2:
buprenorphine 
- partial agonist, prevents full agonists from activating receptor 
- reduces craving
- prevents withdrawal 
- less overdose risk than methadone

column1: describe the MOA of alcohol
column2:
- enhance GABAergic and glycinergic synaptic transmission --> ⇑ inhibition
- inhibition Cav
- activation Kav
- inhibition of GABA receptor function
- inhibition of adenosine transport

column1: describe some of the treatments used in alcohol addiction
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe how making alcohol unpleasant treats alcohol addiction. give an example of the drug and its MOA
column2:
disulfiram
- inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase
- causes flush, palpitations, nausea if you drink alcohol
- can't be used to treat cravings but can be used to treat cue-induced drug-seeking

column1: describe how acamprosate is used to treat alcohol addiction
column2:
- may act via inhibition of NMDA receptor (may alter plasticity)
- may alter GABA and glutmate synaptic transmission
-similar efficacy to naltrexone

column1: describe how topiramate is used to treat alcohol addiction
column2:
- antiepileptic
- may alter phosphorylation of Nav, Cav, GABA & glutamate channels
- may ⇑ GABA and ⇓glutamate synaptic transmission
- may have better treatment outcomes in ppl w kainate polymorphisms
- significant reduction  in drinking but variable results

column1: what is the difference between sedatation and hypnosis
column2:
sedation = ⇓ excitement, vigilance and physiological arousal to induce relaxation, possibly sleepy
hypnosis = ability to induce drowsiness and sleep

column1: describe the MOA of benzodiazepines
column2:
- PAM of GABAA. binds between ⍺ and 𝛾 subunits (GABAA is a pentamer, on postsynaptic neuron)
- ⇑ GABA's affinity for receptor and as a result ⇑ # of channel openings
- causes Cl- influx in post-synaptic neuron causes ⇑ hyperpolarisation and ⇓ in excitability

column1: describe the MOA of barbiturates
column2:
- PAM of GABAA
- agonist at very high doses
- ⇑ length of channel opening

column1: describe how the type ⍺ subunit of a GABA<sub>A </sub>receptor determines the effect of a benzodiazepine
column2:
⍺1 --> sedative/hypnotic, anticonvulsant 
⍺2 and ⍺3 --> anxiolytic 
⍺3 and ⍺3 --> muscle relaxing

column1: describe the MOA of Z-drugs
column2:
- not benzodiazepines because they lack benzodiazepine structure but they act at benzo site on GABAA
- show some preference for ⍺1 (sedative, hypnotic)
- may produce bizarre sleep behaviours

column1: describe the MOA of antihistamine use in sedation
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the MOA of melatonin use in sedation
column2:
- endogenous melatonin is synthesised in pineal gland
- melatonin is an agonist at MT1 and MT2 receptors (both Gi/o coupled GPCRs)
- MT1 --> activation promotes sleep onset
- MT2 --> activation shifts circadian timing

column1: identify the NTs that are present in the ARAS (ascending reticular activation system) and the NTs that are sleep promoting
column2:
ARAS = wakefulness promoting --> NA, 5HT, ACh, dopamine, histamine
sleep promoting --> GABA, adenosine, melatonin

column1: what are some problems associated with benzodiazepine usage?
column2:
- shouldn't be used for >1 month
- when stopping, udose needs to be tapered down
- large dependence liability
- strange sleep behaviours
- amnesia
- combination with other sedatives (eg alcohol) can be v dangerous

column1: describe the advantages and disadvantages of using benzodiazepines to treat anxiety
column2:
recall: ⍺2 and ⍺3 subunits of GABAA promote anxiolytic
alprazolam and clonazepam used bc they show preference for ⍺2
advantage --> rapid onset ∴ good for acute treatment
disadvantage --> dependence potential, drowsiness

column1: what is anxiety and what brain regions does it involve
column2:
"state of preparation for danger (eg ⇑ arousal) but no immediate danger"
- amygdala is up-regulated in fear disorders 
- anxiety thought to be result of problems w synaptic plasticity in Amy circuits

column1: what are the current treatments for anxiety and briefly describe their MOA
column2:
- cognitive behavioural therapy
- benzodiazepines --> GABAA PAM
- SSRIs
- SNRIs
- TCAs: prevent NA and 5HT reuptake
- pregabalin --> GABA analogue that actions on ⍺2δ subtype of Cav to ⇑ GABA levels
- buspirone --> partial 5HT1A (Gi/o) agonist. moderate efficacy

column1: what is schizophrenia?
column2:
- a disorder of higher cognitive functioning caused by abnormalities in the brain (structural - white matter, ventricles, neurochemical - NTs, receptors)
- neurodevelopmental disorder not neurodegenerative
cause:
- genetic?
- pre/perinatal factors
- drug use 
- stress from major life events

column1: describe the general MOA of antipsychotics
column2:
- all are D2 dopamine receptor (Gi) antagonists 
- linear correlation between therapeutic efficacy and affinity for D2

column1: describe the dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia
column2:
dopaminergic dysfunction is what causes schizophrenia
1. ⇑ DA levels, synthesis and release in NAc, Hipp
2. ⇓ other NTs (eg GABA, glutmate) lead to DA dysregulation
3. D2 receptors are supersensitive --> blockade ⇓ overactivity and alleviates psychosis

column1: what are the +ve and -ve symptoms of schizophrenia
column2:
positive:
- hallucinations
- delusions
- disorganised thought & speech
negative:
- anhedonia
- aviolation/apathy (⇓ goal directed activities)
- flattened effect (reduced mood)

column1: which neural pathways are responsible for the +ve and -ve symptoms of schizophrenia
column2:
mesolimbic pathway: VTA --> NAc, Amy, Hipp (dopaminergic). Hyperactivity causes positive symptoms
mesocortical pathway: VTA --> FC (dopaminergic). Hyperactivity causes negative symptoms
nigrostriatal pathway: substantia nigra --> dorsal striatum. Hyperactivity causes cognitive symptoms. Hyperactivity correlates w symptom severity

column1: what are the major classes of typical antipsychotics and give an example. what is their therapeutic effect?
column2:
1. phenothiazines eg chlorpromazine
2. butyrophenones eg haloperidol
3. thioxanthenes
these ameliorate the positive symptoms of schizophrenia but have little effect on negative and cognitive symptoms.

column1: what are the major classes of atypical antipsychotics and give an example. what is their therapeutic effect?
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the receptor actions of typical antipsychotics
column2:
- potent D2 receptor agonists (80% occupany for therapeutic, slow dissociation)
- moderate affinity for ⍺-adrenoceptors and 5-HT2 receptors
- weak affinity for D1, D4, H1 and mACh

column1: describe the receptor actions of atypical antipsychotics
column2:
- D2 antagonism w high affinity and/or selectivity, 60% occupancy at therapeutic doses
- high affinity for 5-HT2 (up to 90% occupancy)
- moderate affinity for ⍺-adrenoceptors and D3
- clozapine & olanzapine have high affinity for D4

column1: compare and contrast the side effects of typical and atypical antipsychotics
column2:
typical:
- movement disorders (associated w D2)
- anticholinergic
- endocrine (weight gain associated w 5-HT2A)
atypical:
- agranulocytosis (clozapine)
- metabolic syndrome

column1: how do antipsychotics work in the short term & long term
column2:
short term:
- blocking D2 autoreceptors ⇑ DA release
- blocking supersensitive D2 postsynaptic receptors ⇓ DA inhibition
long term:
- upregulation of presynaptic D2 ⇓ DA release
- blockade and upregulation of D2 restores homeostasis

column1: what is dementia
column2:
"clinical syndrome associated w impaired memory and other intellectual functions which intefere with normal functioning and impair quality of life"
- progressive decline in mental function
- alzheimers disease accounts for 70% of dementia cases
- stroke and parkinsons each account for 15% of dementia cases

column1: describe the clinical features of alzheimers
column2:
- changes in memory and cognition
- changes in spatial and temporal orientation
- difficulty forming new memories
- altered judgement
- +/- moodiness, depression, apathy

column1: identify & describe the pathological features of alzheimers
column2:
1. cerebral atrophy and ventricular enlargement (cavities that store CSF)
2. neuronal loss with gliosis (particularly cholinergic neurons, gliosis = scarring, occurs in Hipp, Amy, Cortex)
3. amyloid plaques (aggregation of amyloid proteins, most commonly amyloid-β peptide (39-44aa's long))
4. neurofibrillary tangles (abnormal bunches of filament in neurons, hyperphosphorylated tau protein (microtubule associated protein))

column1: describe the neurochemistry of alzheimers with reference to NTs
column2:
ACh - deficit in central cholinergic transmission:
- neuronal loss
- ⇓ choline acetyltransferase (synthesis)
- ⇓ AChE
- ⇓ choline uptake
Amines:
- ⇓ NA synthesis (from loss of cells in locus coeruleus)
- ⇓ 5HT synthesis (from loss of cells in raphe nuclei)
Glutamate:
- ⇓ glutamate transporters
- ⇑ excitotoxicity

column1: describe the genetics of alzheimers
column2:
≥95% cases of alzheimers are sporadic (no genetic basis)
- amyloid precursor protein gene on chromosome 21
- presenelins (PS1 and PS2) genes on chromosome 1, 14 --> may effect processing of APP (more Ab42 and Ab40, Ab42 most commonly found in amyloid plaques)
- apolipoprotein (apoE) --> determines age of onset. ε4 allele = onset in 80s, ε3 allele = onset in 90s

column1: identify different pharmacological treatments for alzheimers
column2:
- cholinesterase inhibitors
- NMDA antagonist 
- antidepressants
- β-secretase inhibitors (alters peptide cleavage to produce less Ab42) --> experimental, low efficacy
- statins (prophylactic?) --> cholesterol plays a role in APP synthesis
- Aducanumab --> immunotherapy targets Aβ plaques in ppl w alzheimers to reduce their build up. serious side effects

column1: what happens when you react two glucose molecules? draw the curly arrow mechanism and name the product
column2: product is a disaccharide. similar to formation of a glycoside but the alcohol is just a substituent of glucose ring.

column1: what is an amino sugar?
column2:
where an -OH group of a sugar is replaced by -NH2
this can be further functionalised by acetylation

column1: starch, glycogen and cellulose are all polymers of glucose. what makes them different from each other?
column2:
have different chain branching patterns
e.g. starch branches ⍺(1-->6) 
NB: in glycogen m=6-12
e.g. cellulose has β(1-->4) linkage (no branching?). therefore humans cant get energy from cellulose bc we dont have the enzyme to hydrolyse this bond

column1: describe how sugars determine blood type
column2: #NAME?

column1: give some examples of sugars being used as drugs
column2:
1. mannitol --> osmotic agent, draws water into airways, useful in improving lung function in CF
2. penicillin --> bacterias have sugars we dont have (NAM and NAG). penicillin inteferes w NAM branching

column1: why do sugars cause a sweet taste?
column2: they contain the right # of H bond donors and H bond acceptors to interact w GPCRs to cause signalling cascade to brain that is interpreted as sweet tasting

column1: describe the role of cyclodextrins in food and give an example
column2:
cyclodextrin = cyclic polysaccharide which has a cavity that can bind molecules. 
e.g. cholesterol free eggs:
1. whites & yolks are separated
2. β-cyclodextrin is mixed w yolks to create a crystalline complex of β-cyclodextrin and cholesterol which is removed w centrifugion
3. add yolks and whites together and you have cholesterol free eggs

column1: describe the maillard reaction
column2:
upon heating, amino acids react w reducing sugars
then form an imine then undergo amadori rearrangement (aldose --> ketose)
then a sequence of rxns occur to form aromatic products that are responsible for the colour and taste of many diff foods

column1: what are lipids
column2: #NAME?

column1: what are some functions of lipids
column2:
1. storage --> of energy
2. membranes --> water insolubility makes lipids excellent barriers for delineating cells and organelles
3. messengers --> steroids, prostaglandins and thromboxanes are all lipids

column1: identify this molecule
column2: prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) --> inflammatory mediator

column1: identify this molecule
column2: thromboxane A2

column1: identify this molecule
column2: estrogen

column1: identify this molecule
column2: cholesterol

column1: identify this molecule
column2: testosterone

column1: describe the nomenclature of unsaturated fatty acids
column2:
C(C chain length):(#double bonds) cis/trans Δ(number of carbons away from COOH that double bond is)
e.g. C18:1 cis Δ9

column1:
saturated fatty acids have _____ melting & boiling points
unsaturated fatty acids have ______ melting & boiling points
column2:
1. high (bc they have 'straight' carbon chains which ⇑ dispersion forces)
2. low

column1: describe the three types of complex lipids and give their general structure
column2:
1. glycerophospholipids

2. sphingolipids

3. glycolipids

column1: which alcohols are usually found in glycerophospholipids/phosphoglycerides
column2:
ethanolamine
choline
serine
inositol

column1: if the alcohol in a glycerophospholipid is ethanolamine or serine what is the lipid called?
column2: a cephalin

column1: if the alcohol in a glycerophospholipid is choline what is the lipid called?
column2: lecithin

column1: describe the structure of sphingolipids
column2: built around the poly-ol sphingosine rather than glycerol

column1: describe the function of sphingomyelin
column2: component of myelin sheath, which insulates nerves

column1: describe the structure of glycolipids
column2:
glycerol backbone. contain a sugar (can be mono or polysaccharide) but no phosphate
sphingoglycolipids have a sphingosine scaffold but contain a sugar

column1: describe the different structures than can arise from lipid self
column2:
planar bilayer sheet 
micelle = spherical single layer
liposome = spherical bilayer

column1: describe how lipid structure influences phase transitions
column2:
phase transition temperature = Tt
- saturated FAs have ⇑Tt bc ⇑VDW forces and more efficient packing
- unsaturated FAs (particularly cis) have ⇓Tt bc chain kink disturbs packing and ⇓VDW forces

column1: describe the basic principles of differential scanning calorimetry and its usage in detecting changes in phase
column2:
heat a sample & a reference continually and measure ΔT between them
if both have same heat capacity, ΔT = 0
if a phase change occurs, ΔT > 0
this means the heat capacity of the sample, which you measure?

column1: what is the core ring system of steroid hormones and describe the numbering system
describe the biosynthetic origin and function of cholesterol
column2:
- most important 'steroid' in human body
- made in the liver
- starting material for testosterone, estrogen, bile salts etc
- essential component of cell membrane (up to 50% of plasma membrane)
- modulated function of membrane proteins e.g. Na+/K+ ATPase

column1: describe how cholesterol is transported throughout the body
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the difference between VLDL, LDL and HDL
column2:
VLDL = very low density lipoprotein
- produced by liver
- triglyceride rich
- pro-atherogenic 
LDL = low density lipoprotein
- derived from VLDL/IDL and are even more enriched in cholesterol
- carries the majority of cholesterol thats in circulation
HDL = high density lipoprotein
- transports cholesterol to liver where its excreted as bile
- transports cholesterol to organs where it is used to synthesise hormones

column1: describe cholesterol transport by VLDL and LDL
column2:
- carry cholesterol from liver to body
- LDL receptors on cells 'meet and greet' LDL
- high levels of LDL in blood linked to atherosclerosis (deposition of lipids and cholesterol into arterial wall)

column1: what is the MOA of statins?
column2: #NAME?

column1: what is the biosynthetic origin of sex hormones
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the biosynthetic origin and function of bile salts
column2:
- products of cholesterol metabolism
- stereochemistry bottom face of molecule is hydrophilic and the top face is hydrophobic
- natural surfactants --> solubilise fats and assist in their absorption

column1: describe the biosynthetic origin and function of prostaglandins
column2:
- synthesised from arachidonic acid (oxidative ring closure catalysed by cyclooxygenase)
- key signalling molecules:
--> stimulate uterine contractions (labour)
--> relax muscles around blood vessels (lower blood pressure)

column1: describe the biosynthetic origin and function of thromboxane
column2:
- synthesised from PGH2
- signalling molecule
- induces platelet aggregation --> first step in blood clotting

column1: describe the biosynthetic origin and function of leukotrienes
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe membrane asymmetry with reference to the different types of lipids
column2: #NAME?

column1: how is membrane asymmetry maintained
column2:
flippases, flopases 
ATP dependent enzymes which translocate phospholipids

column1: describe which direction flippase, floppase and scramblase translocate phospholipids
column2:
flippase = outer leaflet --> inner leaf
floppase = inner leaflet --> outer leaflet
scramblase = antiporter

column1: describe how membrane asymmetry across different organisms can be exploited in medicine
column2:
- bacteria have different lipid distribution & asymmetry in their membranes
- PE and PG are major lipid components of bacterial membranes. PC is major one in animals
- can use this fact to target specific bacteria with new antimicrobials

column1: describe how membrane asymmetry can be exploited in medicine
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the timescale of lipid movement in a membrane
column2:
rotational lipid rocking 10-9s
lateral movement 10-6s
transverse "flip flop" 105s (seldom happens w/o an enzyme)

column1: how is lipid rocking measured and describe the basic principles
column2:
- measured using fluoresence anisotropy (FA)
- based off principle that light emitted by a fluorophore has unequal intensities along diff axes of polarisation
- measure FA (which is r) by fluoresence intensity
- calculate rotational correlation time ɸ (ie time for a molecule to rotate by one radian)

column1: how is lipid lateral movement measured and describe the basic principles
column2:
- measure using fluoresence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP)
- measures translational diffusion coefficients
- steps are bleach molecule of interest w fluoro tag (∴no more fluoresence), and time how bleached area recovers as non-bleached molecules diffuse in

column1: how is lipid transverse movement measured and describe the basic principles
column2:
- measured using electron paramagnetic response spectroscopy
- determines kinetics of flip flop
- bascially add a nitroxide radical (paramagnetic) to some PCs in lipid bilayer --> produces EPR signal
- add ascorbate which reduces nitroxide to be diagmagnetic --> no EPR signal

column1: to form an ordered structure...
column2: the energy of bond formation must overcome the randomising effect of kinetic energy

column1: what is the assembly of small molecules into organised structures governed by
column2:
boltzmann distribution

IMFs driving formation of structures must exceed thermal energy

column1: what determines whether a water-in-oil or oil-in-water emulsion will form?
column2:
which is the major component of the mixture
if water --> oil-in-water
if oil --> water-in-oil (these are called reverse micelles)

column1: how is soap prepared and how does it clean dirt?
column2:
- saponification of fatty acids by treatment w NaOH gives 1 molecule of glycerol and 3 molecules of sodium sterate (which is a soap)
- sodium sterate can form micelles and encapsulate dirt

column1: describe how molecule structure determines structure shape
column2:
- determined by critical packing parameter v/(a0lc), which relates volume of surfactant tail, area occupied by headgroup and length of surfactant tail
- if v/(a0lc) < 1/3 --> spherical micelle
- if 1/2 < v/(a0lc) < 1 --> vesicle 
- if v/(a0lc) = 1 --> planar bilayer
- is v/(a0lc) > 1 --> reverse micelle

column1: describe the nature of gels
column2: #NAME?

column1: describe the hydrophobic effect
describe π-π stacking
column2:

column1: what is osmotic pressure
column2: the amount of force applied to a solution that prevents solvent from moving across a semipermeable membrane.

column1: how is osmotic pressure measured
column2:
- osmometer
- two chambers separated by semipermeable membrane
- each chamber has a capillary sticking up
- solvent flows to the solution side to produce hydrostatic pressure which opooses further flow
- π is calculated using difference of heights of liquid of the solutions

p=1x103 kg m-3

column1: how to calculate the osmotic pressure of an ideal solution
what is an ideal solution
column2: enthalpy of mixing = 0

column1: what is chemical potential and how can it be used to understand osmotic pressure
column2:
it is the gibbs free energy per mole of solute in solution (µi)
water will flow from a high chemical potential (solvent) to low chemical potential (solution)
at equilibrium the chemical potential of a given component but be everywhere equal
in non-ideal conditions:


where gamma is just a correction factor called the activity coefficient (no units - is there so only the molecules contributing to chemical potential are contributing to ther eqn)

column1: describe the donnan effect
column2:
the uneven distribution of ions across a cell membrane is due to the large amounts of impermable anionic macromolecules(mostly proteins) and organic phosphates in the cytoplasm
more K+ inside cell, more Cl- outside cell

column1: why must Na+ be continuously pumped out of cells?
column2:
⇓ # of particles in the cell
hence ⇓ osmotic pressure
prevents cell from swelling and possibly bursting

column1: describe the transport of ions by Na+/K+ ATPase
column2:
efflux of 3Na+ and influc of 2K+ per 1 hydrolysis of ATP
(active transport)

column1: what is the nernst equation and what does it describe
column2: measures membrane potential Vm (electrical potential difference across a membrane)

column1: how can you determine whether the dsitribution of ions across a membrane is at equilibrium
column2:
eq when Vmexp ≈ Vm
if Vmexp >> Vm, or Vmexp << Vm then the ions distribution is far from eq and ions must actively be being transported/pumped across the membrane

column1: what is the difference between equilibrium and steady state
column2:
if membrane potential is constant, this means no net current flowing across membrane and flux of cations and anions cancel out
ɸK++ ɸNa++ ɸCl- = 0
this is the steady state approximation
diff from eq as steady state is maintained by expenditure of energy (ATP), cell goes eq when it dies

column1: rank the ability of anions, cations and nonelectrolytes to cross the cell membrane with reference to their permeability coefficients
column2:
cations < anions < nonelectrolytes(uncharged, polar)
cations have low permeability coefficient Pd 
nonelectrolytes have higher Pd
anions in between

column1: what is the equation for born energy and what does it describe?
column2:
- describes the electrostatic energy necessary to transfer an ion from water into the membrane

multiply by avogadros number to get answer for one mole of ions

column1: describe the principles of noise analysis and what it measures
column2:
- measures the current across the cell membrane as a function of time
- speed of current fluctuations is measures as the autocorrelation function G(τ)
- long τc --> channels are opening and closing slowly
- short τc --> channels are opening and closing quickly

column1: describe the principles of patch clamp and what it measures
column2:
- measures the flow of current across a membrane
1. suck a small area of membrane into a pipette (3-4nm across)
2. hope membrane patch has a channel and doesn't burst
3. measure fluctuations in current as a function of time and applied voltage
- 1pA measurable current

column1: describe how is the Na+ gradient across a membrane a store of energy
column2:
ΔG = -50kJ mol-1 (ATP --> ADP + Pi)
ΔG = +36kJ mol-1 (for movement of Na+ and K+ by ATPase)
there's 14kJmol of energy from ATP hydrolysis which is released as heat --> if ATP hydrolysis occured w/o membrane no work would be done (all would be released as heat)
e.g.
Na+ gradient facilitates glucose reabsorption absorbtion (glucose reabs by itself is unfavourable, but Na+ transport makes it so ΔµNa+ + ΔµG < 0)
